00018 namespace RandomLib {
00019   /**
00020    * \brief Sample exactly from a power distribution.
00021    *
00022    * Sample exactly from power distribution (<i>n</i> + 1)
00023    * <i>x</i><sup><i>n</i></sup> for \e x in (0,1) and integer \e n >= 0 using
00024    * infinite precision.  The template parameter \e bits specifies the number
00025    * of bits in the base used for RandomNumber (i.e., base =
00026    * 2<sup><i>bits</i></sup>).
00027    *
00028    * This class uses some mutable RandomNumber objects.  So a single ExactPower
00029    * object cannot safely be used by multiple threads.  In a multi-processing
00030    * environment, each thread should use a thread-specific ExactPower object.
00031    * In addition, these should be invoked with thread-specific random generator
00032    * objects.
00033    *
00034    * @tparam bits the number of bits in each digit.
00035    **********************************************************************/
00036   template<int bits = 1> class ExactPower {
00037   public:
00038     /**
00039      * Return the random deviate with a power distribution, (<i>n</i> + 1)
00040      * <i>x</i><sup><i>n</i></sup> for \e x in (0,1) and integer \e n >= 0.
00041      * Returned result is a RandomNumber with base 2<sup><i>bits</i></sup>.
00042      * For \e bits = 1, the number of random bits in the result and consumed
00043      * are as follows:\n
00044 \verbatim
00045       n    random bits
00046           result  consumed
00047       0   0        0
00048       1   2        4
00049       2   2.33     6.67
00050       3   2.67     9.24
00051       4   2.96    11.71
00052       5   3.20    14.11
00053       6   3.41    16.45
00054       7   3.59    18.75
00055       8   3.75    21.01
00056       9   3.89    23.25
00057      10   4.02    25.47
00058 \endverbatim
00059      * The relative frequency of the results with \e bits = 1 and \e n = 2 can
00060      * be is shown by the histogram\n
00061      * <img src="powerhist.png" width=580 height=750
00062      *      alt="exact binary sampling of power distribution">\n
00063      * The base of each rectangle gives the range represented by the
00064      * corresponding binary number and the area is proportional to its
00065      * frequency.  A PDF version of this figure
00066      * <a href="powerhist.pdf">here</a>.  This allows the figure to be
00067      * magnified to show the rectangles for all binary numbers up to 9 bits.
00068      *
00069      * @tparam Random the type of the random generator.
00070      * @param[in,out] r a random generator.
00071      * @param[in] n the power.
00072      * @return the random sample.
00073      **********************************************************************/
00074     template<class Random>
00075     RandomNumber<bits> operator()(Random& r, unsigned n) const;
00076   private:
00077     mutable RandomNumber<bits> _x;
00078     mutable RandomNumber<bits> _y;
00079   };
00080 
00081   template<int bits> template<class Random> RandomNumber<bits>
00082   ExactPower<bits>::operator()(Random& r, unsigned n) const {
00083     // Return max(u_0, u_1, u_2, ..., u_n).  Equivalent to taking the
00084     // (n+1)th root of u_0.
00085     _x.Init();
00086     for (; n--;) {
00087       _y.Init();
00088       // For bits = 1, we can save 1 bit on the first iteration by using a
00089       // technique suggested by Knuth and Yao (1976).  When comparing the
00090       // digits of x and y, use 1 bit to determine if the digits are the same.
00091       // If they are, then use another bit for the value of the digit.  If they
00092       // are not, then the next bit of the maximum must be 1 (avoiding using a
00093       // second bit).  Applying this optimization to subsequent iterations
00094       // (when x already is filled with some bits) gets trickier.
00095       if (_x.LessThan(r, _y))
00096         _x.swap(_y);            // x = y;
00097     }
00098     return _x;
00099   }
00100 } // namespace RandomLib
